case_name: Central National Bank Limited v. the defendant bank

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1953 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 32 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th March, 1951,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 12th March 1951 of Calcutta High Court appellate bench (Harries J. and Banerjee J.).

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th March, 1951, of the High Court of judicature at Calcutta  Harries J. and Banerjee J.  in Appeal from Original Decree dated the 21st March, 1950,

facts.text: Reversing decision of single Judge dated 21st March 1950 in Suit No. 1112 of 1946 in Calcutta High Court Original Side.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal from Original Decree dated the 21st March, 1950, of the Calcutta High Court in its ordinary original civil jurisdiction in Suit No. 1112 of 1946.

facts.text: Suit No. 1112 of 1946 commenced by Central National Bank Limited (appellant) in Original Side of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit, out of which this appeal arises, was companymenced by the Central National Bank Limited, the appellant before us, in the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, for a declaration

facts.text: Suit for declaration that bank acquired rights of pledgee in respect of 800 shares in Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. and Steel Corporation of Bengal Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that the bank acquired the rights of a pledgee in respect of two blocks Of shares in two companypanies, to wit, the Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd. and the Steel Corporation of Bengal Ltd.

facts.text: Shares were property of Radhika Mohan Bhuiya, defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The shares, to which the dispute relates, are 800 in number and admittedly they were the property of one Radhika Mohan Bhuiya, the defendant No. 2 in the suit.

facts.text: In February 1946, Bhuiya agreed to sell shares to Dwijendra Nath Mukherjee for Rs. 38,562-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in February, 1946, Bhuiya agreed to sell these shares to one Dwijendra Nath Mukherjee for the price of Rs. 38,562-8-0.

facts.text: On 14th February 1946, Bhuiya sent shares and transfer deeds to defendant bank with instructions to deliver against payment.

anchor.surface_text: On 14th February, 1946, Bhuiya sent these shares along with the relative transfer deeds to the defendant bank with instructions to deliver over the share certificates and the transfer deeds to the purchaser,

facts.text: On 18th February 1946, defendant bank directed Nilkrishna Paul to deliver shares to Mukherjee after receiving pay order for Rs. 38,562-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th of February following, the defendant bank directed one of its officers, to wit, Nilkrishna Paul, to see Mukherjee at his office and hand over to him the shares after receiving from him a pay order

facts.text: Paul met Mukherjee at his office around 11 a.m. on 18th February 1946.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with this direction, Paul went to the ,office of Mukherjee and saw him at his chamber at about 11 a.m. in the morning.

facts.text: Mukherjee examined shares and transfer deeds on the table in Paul's presence.

anchor.surface_text: After that Paul placed the shares and the transfer deeds on the table. Mukherjee examined the share certificates one after another

facts.text: Mukherjee took shares saying he was going to get the pay order and would return, but did not return.

anchor.surface_text: when he was about to leave the chamber along with the share certificates and the ranK transfer deeds, Paul raised an objection... Mukherjee then said to Paul I am going out to get the pay order it is ready. You take your seat I am companying. With these words Mukherjee went out

facts.text: Mukherjee pledged shares with plaintiff bank, received Rs. 29,000 advance via overdraft on new account opened with Rs. 100 cheque, executed promissory note.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that he went straight to the office of the plaintiff bank and pledged the shares with it, taking an advance of Rs. 29,000... Mukherjee gave a cheque for Rs. 100 with which an account in Ms name was opened... Mukherjee also executed a promissory numbere

facts.text: Mukherjee has not been heard of since and whereabouts unknown.

anchor.surface_text: It is, the companymon case of the parties that Mukherjee has number been heard of since then and his present whereabouts are unknown.

facts.text: Paul waited and then reported to superior, police complaint lodged by defendant bank.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to Paul, the defendants, officer, after waiting vainly for Mukherjee he had numberother alternative but to companye back to his office and inform his superior officer of all that had happened. A companyplaint was then lodged with the police

facts.text: Rs. 100 cheque to plaintiff dishonored.

anchor.surface_text: The cheque, which was given to the plaintiff by Mukherjee, was dishonored when it was presented for payment.

facts.text: Plaintiff bank sold shares through broker Jalan, received Rs. 16,000 cheque, payment stopped, police took possession of shares.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff sold these shares through a broker named jalan. jalan took delivery of the shares and gave the plaintiff a cheque for Rs. 16,000 in part payment of the price. The payment of the cheque, however, was stopped and the police... took possession of the shares.

facts.text: Criminal case against Shaw (accomplice of Mukherjee) unsuccessful, Shaw acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: As Mukherjee companyld number be traced, a criminal case was started against an alleged accomplice of his, named Shaw, but this proved unsuccessful and Shaw was acquitted.

facts.text: Defendant bank paid full price to Bhuiya.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant bank, who had paid the full price of these shares to Bhuiya,

facts.text: Defendant bank applied to Magistrate for return of shares as owner.

anchor.surface_text: then presented an application to the Magistrate, praying that the shares might be returned to it on the ground of its being the owner thereof.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit upon information of defendant's application.

anchor.surface_text: On getting information of this application, the plaintiff bank instituted the present suit,

facts.text: Mukherjee did not acquire legal title to shares; only agreement for sale, property passes on payment.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that Mukherjee did number acquire any legal title to the shares. There was only an agreement for sale between him and Bhuiya, and under the terms of,the companytract the property in the shares companyld number pass to him till the price was paid.

facts.text: Plaintiff not pledgee from real owner.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff bank, therefore Was number a pledgee of the shares from the real owner.

facts.text: Trial judge Mr. Justice Sarkar decreed suit for plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Sarkar of the Calcutta High Court, who tried the suit, decided this question in favour of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Appellate bench (Harries CJ and Banerjee J) allowed appeal, reversed trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges allowed the appeal and reversed the judgment of the trial companyrt holding that the defendants agent never companysented to Mukherjees obtaining possession of the shares as buyer.

facts.text: Paul instructed not to deliver shares without payment.

anchor.surface_text: Sachindra Sen... says in his deposition, that he definitely instructed Paul number to deliver the shares unless he received payment.

facts.text: Paul placed shares on table for Mukherjee to examine, retained control.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that when Paul placed the share certificates upon the table and allowed Mukherjee to scrutinise them, he did number part with the possession of or companytrol over the shares.

facts.text: Paul objected to Mukherjee leaving with shares without pay order.

anchor.surface_text: When Mukherjee was about to leave the chamber, I told him number to go away but to give me the pay order.

facts.text: Court found Mukherjee did not get possession with consent of Paul.

anchor.surface_text: on the evidence on the record, we do number think it possible to hold that he got possession with the companysent of Paul.

facts.text: Paul waited 2-3 minutes, then searched for Mukherjee who was not there.

anchor.surface_text: Paul says in his deposition that he waited for 2 or 3 minutes, and when Mukherjee did number companye back, he became anxious and went out of the chamber towards the companynter where he found an old gentleman sitting.

It rested its claim entirely upon the provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act, the language of which is as follows - Where a person, having bought or agreed to buy goods, obtains, with the companysent of the seller, possession of the goods or the documents of title to the goods,

concepts.interpretation: Protects good faith recipient of pledge/sale from buyer in possession with seller's consent; consent determined by Contract Act s13; fraud does not negate consent unless rendering transaction void ab initio (e.g., identity mistake).
concepts.unlisted_label: Section 30(2) Indian Sale of Goods Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Buyer in possession with consent of seller can pass good title to bona fide transferee.

issues.text: whether on the facts that transpired in evidence, the plaintiff bank was entitled to avail itself of the provision of section 30 2 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act

anchor.surface_text: The whole controversy thus centeredround the point as to whether on the facts that transpired in evidence, the plaintiff bank was entitled to avail itself of the provision of section 30 2  of the Indian Sale of Goods Act.

issues.text: whether the consent necessary under section 30 2 of the Sale of Goods Act must be a free consent uninfluenced by fraud or false representation

anchor.surface_text: The two principal questions that require consideration are first, whether the consent necessary under section 30 2 of the Sale of Goods Act must be a free consent uninfluenced by fraud or false representation,

issues.text: whether the existence of such consent is negatived, as a matter of law, if a person of the requisite description mentioned in the section obtains possession of goods from the owner by trick or other deceitful means which makes his act punishable as a crime

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, whether the existence of such consent is negatived, as a matter of law, it a person of the requisite description mentioned in the section obtains possession of goods from the owner by trick or other deceitful means which makes his act punishable as a crime.

holdings.text: The word 'consent' as used in section 30(2) of the Sale of Goods Act means agreeing on the same thing in the same sense as defined in section 13 of the Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned counsel on both sides that the word consent as used in section 30 2 of the Sale of Goods Act means agreeing on the same thinging the same sense as defined in section 13 of the Indian Contract Act. There is no definition of consent in the Sale of Goods Act itself, but section 2 15 of the Act definitely lays down that the expressions used and not defined in the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.2(15) SOGA to incorporate ICA definitions; agreed by both counsel.

holdings.text: Consent under section 30(2) need not be 'free consent' under section 14 of the Contract Act; consent induced by fraud is real though voidable, sufficient to protect innocent pledgee until avoided.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Contract Act defines the expression free consent and a consent is free when it is not caused by coercion, under influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake. A consent induced by false representation may not be free,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes real consent (s13) from free consent (s14); fraud renders voidable not void; protects commerce by safeguarding innocent transferees; supported by English authorities like Cahn and Pearson.

holdings.text: Fraud causing error as to identity of person renders transaction void ab initio with no real consent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No consensus ad idem where fundamental mistake as to identity; cites Lake v Simmons.

holdings.text: Existence of consent under section 30(2) not negatived merely because possession obtained by trick, deceit, or criminal offence like larceny by trick; no importation of English criminal law fictions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Consent determined by civil contract law, not criminal intent; rejects larceny by trick distinction as fiction unsuitable for commercial statute; prefers Folkes v King over conflicting English cases; policy to protect commerce.

holdings.text: Mukherjee did not obtain possession of the shares with the consent of the seller's agent Paul.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Paul placed shares for inspection only, retained control; objected when Mukherjee tried to leave without payment; Mukherjee bolted without giving opportunity for assent or reliance on promise; evidence of Paul credible.

holdings.text: Plaintiff bank not entitled to protection under section 30(2) of the Sale of Goods Act; appellate High Court view correct.

anchor.surface_text: The whole controversy thus centered round the point as to whether on the facts that transpired in evidence, the plaintiff bank was entitled to avail itself of the provision of section 30 2 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No consent on facts despite good faith; applies s30(2) requirements strictly.

precedents.citation: Cahn v. Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company 1

anchor.surface_text: In Cahn v. Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company 1 , Collins J. made the following oftquoted observation - However fraudulent a person in actual custody may have been, in obtaining the possession, provided it does number amount to larceny by trick

precedents.case_name: Cahn v Pocketts Bristol Channel Steam Packet Company
precedents.cited_proposition: However fraudulent a person in actual custody may have been in obtaining possession, provided it does not amount to larceny by trick, he can give good title to purchaser
precedents.cited_holding: However fraudulent a person in actual custody may have been, in obtaining the possession, provided it does number amount to larceny by trick and however grossly he may abuse companyfidence reposed in him, or violate the mandate under which he got possession, he can, by his disposition, give a good title to the purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: Vide the cases referred to by Scrutton L. J. in Folks King 1923, I K.B. 282 at 301. 3 1950 2 All E.R. 1027 at 1032. England and in our opinion it does number exclude the operation of section 30 2  of the Sale of Goods Act in India.

precedents.cited_proposition: Cases referred to by Scrutton L.J. regarding the main proposition in Cahn

anchor.surface_text: The law on this point has been thus summed up by Denning L. J. in Pearson v. Rose 3  The effect of fraud is as a rule only to make the transaction voidable and number void, and if,. therefore, an innocent purchaser has bought the goods before the transaction is avoided the true owner cannot claim them back.

precedents.cited_proposition: Effect of fraud is to make transaction voidable not void; consent obtained by fraud enables Factors Act to operate until avoided
precedents.cited_holding: The effect of fraud is as a rule only to make the transaction voidable and number void... Thus obtaining possession of goods by false pretences does number exclude the operation of the Factors Act

anchor.surface_text: In Lake v. Simmons 1 Lord Haldane made the following observations while dealing with a similar point The appellant thought that he was dealing with a different person, the wife of Van der Borgh, and it was on that footing alone that he parted with the goods.

precedents.cited_proposition: No consent where fraud as to identity of person; no consensus ad idem
precedents.cited_holding: The appellant thought that he was dealing with a different person... There was number the agreement of her mind with that of the seller that was required in order to establish any companytractual right at all.

anchor.surface_text: as was said by Bankes L. J. in Folkes v. King 1 , that is altogether immaterial for the purpose of determining whether there was companysent on the part of the owner of the goods under the Factors Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Dishonest intention of receiver immaterial for determining owner's consent under Factors Act; keep criminal and civil considerations distinct

anchor.surface_text: Vide Whitehorn v. Davison 1911 1 K.B. 463, 479. With regard to the first category of cases,however, the decisions of the English companyrts are number at all uniform.

precedents.cited_proposition: Larceny by trick where no real consent (deceiving as to identity or different goods)

anchor.surface_text: The observation as regards the exception in case of larceny by trick, though it companyld number rank higher than an obiter, was accepted as good law by the Court of Appeal in England in Oppenheimer v. Frazer 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Accepted Collins J's obiter exception for larceny by trick

King 3  that when companysent was In fact given by the owner of the goods, it was immaterial that the receiver was guilty of larceny by trick, and this view was approved of by the majority of the Court of Appeal in Lake v. Simmons 4
